content.text: Not every argument is valid. To show an argument is **invalid**, we find a counterexample: a situation where the premises are true but the conclusion is false.

content.definition: A truth-value assignment (or interpretation) that makes all premises true while making the conclusion false. One counterexample proves an argument invalid.

content.text: Strategy: assume the conclusion is false, then try to make all premises true. If you succeed, you've found a counterexample.

content.note: This assignment makes premises true and conclusion false — the argument is INVALID.

content.text: This argument commits the fallacy of **affirming the consequent**. Just because Q is true and P → Q is true doesn't mean P must be true.
For propositional logic, you can use truth tables systematically: check every row. If any row has true premises and false conclusion, the argument is invalid.

content.question: How do you show an argument is invalid?
options: Find a counterexample with true premises and false conclusion
content.explanation: To show invalidity, find a counterexample: a situation where all premises are true but the conclusion is false. This demonstrates the conclusion doesn't follow from the premises.
